choices.text: Inhibition of the carboxylation of coagulation factors

questions.solution:
Heparin is commonly used for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis in hospitalized patients. It activates antithrombin III, which in turn inactivates factors IIa and Xa, accounting for heparin’s anticoagulant effects.

One toxicity is heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), characterized by a fall in platelet count and a hypercoagulable state. The condition arises when platelet factor 4 (PF4), a substance released from the alpha granule of platelets, binds with heparin molecules. This complex is immunogenic and may cause the formation of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex.

The antibodies then activate platelets, resulting in the microthrombi formation and an overall reduction in the platelet count. The microthrombi can damage a variety of organ systems, including the heart, kidneys, and skin. In addition, antibody-coated platelets are consumed by macrophages, further reducing the platelet count. The reaction usually occurs 5-10 days after heparin initiation and is often associated with a fall in platelet count of 30% or more.

If a patient experiences HIT, heparin should be immediately discontinued. Alternative anticoagulants (e.g., argatroban, fondaparinux) should be initiated to disrupt microthrombi formation.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of ADP-dependent platelet aggregation:
Incorrect: Medications such as clopidogrel inhibit ADP-dependent platelet aggregation. Common side effects include rash and diarrhea. Ticlopidine, an older agent, works via a similar mechanism and can result in neutropenia. However, it would be unusual for any of these medications to cause thrombocytopenia.  
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Aspirin, celecoxib, and NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) work by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes. Side effects include increased risk of bleeding, kidney injury, and interstitial nephritis.  
❌ Inhibition of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (e.g, abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide) work via inhibition of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. These agents can cause acute-onset thrombocytopenia that manifests within 24 hours of starting the medication. In contrast, this patient’s thrombocytopenia was detected almost a week after starting these medications. Moreover, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors are rarely used for clotting prophylaxis after surgery.  
❌ Inhibition of the carboxylation of coagulation factors:
Incorrect: Warfarin inhibits vitamin K-dependent carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Side effects include increased risk of bleeding, transient hypercoagulability, and skin necrosis.  
✅ Activation of antithrombin:
Correct: See the Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) 18 hours after a stab wound to the right anterior chest. On initial presentation, the patient is hemodynamically unstable with absent breath sounds on the right, resulting in chest tube placement that returns 1700 mL of blood within 10 minutes. Given his instability in the trauma bay, a massive transfusion protocol is initiated. He receives 11 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC), 8 units platelets, and 10 units of plasma. He is subsequently taken to the operating room where a distal right subclavian artery injury is identified and repaired. On post-operative evaluation, temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 95/67mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient has blood oozing from all IV sites and the wound site. Which of the following sets of laboratory values is consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Normal Platelet; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Decreased Platelets; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen
Normal Platelets; Normal PT; Prolonged aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Normal Platelet; Prolonged PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen

questions.solution:
This trauma patient is recovering in the ICU after repair of a large vessel injury and a massive transfusion protocol. He received a balanced 1:1:1 transfusion of packed RBCs, platelets, and plasma. Shortly thereafter, he experienced bleeding from multiple wounds and IV sites, which is consistent with consumptive coagulopathy following trauma and massive transfusion protocol. Associated lab values would include decreased platelet count, prolonged PT and aPTT, and a decreased fibrinogen level.         

The cause of coagulopathy following massive transfusion in trauma patients is multifactorial. In trauma patients, tissue trauma, shock, tissue anoxia, and hypothermia contribute to the development of disseminated intravascular coagulation and microvascular bleeding. Additionally, massive transfusion can lead to the consumption of clotting factors. The result is that consumption of platelets and coagulation factors along with significant fibrinolysis can lead to impaired coagulation and bleeding.         

Treatment for coagulopathy following trauma and massive transfusion includes the maintenance of adequate tissue perfusion, the correction of hypothermia and anemia, and the use of antifibrinolytics and other hemostatic blood products. The anti-fibrinolytic agent tranexamic has been shown to improve mortality rates in trauma patients who are bleeding.   

Option Analysis

❌ Normal Platelet; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen:
Incorrect: This patient presents with consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and massive transfusion protocol resulting in abnormal blood oozing from wound and IV sites. This causes abnormalities including Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen. 
❌ Decreased Platelets; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: In patients with isolated thrombocytopenia, platelet numbers decrease, but clotting times and fibrinogen remain unchanged. This can occur in several conditions, including immune thrombocytopenia, liver disease, and bone marrow disorders. This patient with likely consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and massive transfusion protocol would be expected to have Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen. 
✅ Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal Platelets; Normal PT; Prolonged aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: Isolated prolonged aPTT occurs with Hemophilia A or B (Factor VIII or IX deficiency). Consumptive coagulopathy after trauma and massive transfusion is more likely in this patient and would present with Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen  
❌ Normal Platelet; Prolonged PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: Isolated prolonged PT can be caused by Factor VII deficiency. This rare condition is typically discovered during an outpatient workup done for prolonged bleeding. This patient likely has consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and a massive transfusion protocol would be expected to have Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for low blood pressure several hours after an elective left hemicolectomy for malignant-appearing polyps in the descending colon. His past medical history is significant for alcohol-induced cirrhosis and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine and propranolol. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 76/42 mmHg. The patient is given 3 liters of IV 0.9% saline. Repeat blood pressure after fluids is 80/44 mmHg. On examination, the patient is ill-appearing with significant pallor. The abdomen is firm and diffusely tender to palpation. CT imaging of the abdomen shows retroperitoneal fluid with heterogeneous high attenuation. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is found to have postoperative hypotension that is refractory to IV fluid administration. The patient’s underlying cirrhosis (which causes coagulopathy), pallor, and retroperitoneal fluid suggestive of blood on CT imaging indicate retroperitoneal bleeding. This patient has developed postoperative hemorrhagic shock and needs emergent surgical evaluation. The patient should also receive blood products and vasopressors.

Hemorrhagic shock can occur postoperatively, especially after intra-abdominal or lower extremity surgery as these areas can accommodate a large amount of blood. Severe blood loss after surgery manifests as hypotension, which can be associated with weakness, lethargy, and pallor depending upon the amount and speed of blood loss. Laboratory evidence of decreased serum hemoglobin can significantly lag behind the actual degree of blood loss. Therefore, blood products should be transfused in cases of suspected severe blood loss, even if the hemoglobin is not significantly lower than previous measurements or laboratory studies have not yet returned.  

Option Analysis

✅ Return to the operating room:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV fluid bolus:
Incorrect: This patient has already received several liters of IV fluids without meaningful improvement in blood pressure, therefore another IV fluid bolus is unlikely to be of benefit. Instead, this patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the source of bleeding is located in the operating room.  
❌ Octreotide infusion:
Incorrect: Octreotide infusions are indicated in some cases of bleeding esophageal varices. This patient’s CT imaging shows retroperitoneal bleeding for which octreotide would not provide significant benefit. This patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the bleeding source is located in the operating room.  
❌ Paracentesis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture of refractory hypotension, pallor, and retroperitoneal fluid after surgery is highly suggestive of retroperitoneal bleeding. A diagnostic paracentesis is not necessary, and a therapeutic paracentesis would not address the source of bleeding.  
❌ Ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient already has CT imaging highly suggestive of retroperitoneal bleeding, so an ultrasound is not necessary at this point. This patient should be stabilized with blood products and vasopressors for a retroperitoneal bleed while the bleeding source is located in the operating room.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the trauma bay of the emergency department (ED) after involvement in a motor vehicle collision. He was the unrestrained driver in a head-on collision with a truck traveling approximately 50 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the ED, the patient is intubated for airway protection, and shortly thereafter he becomes pulseless. Three rounds of CPR are administered with a return of spontaneous circulation. Massive transfusion protocol (MTP) is initiated. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room and undergoes an uncomplicated splenectomy and liver laceration repair. He is admitted to the ICU for further management. 12 hours after his presentation to the ED, there is blood oozing from multiple lines and wounds. Lab work reveals prolonged aPTT and PT decreased fibrinogen level, and elevated d-dimer. Which of the following physical exam findings would be expected based on this patient’s likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented as an unstable trauma patient requiring immediate intubation and initiation of massive transfusion protocol. Within 12 hours, he is noted to have oozing from multiple sites and lab work reveals prolonged clotting times, decreased fibrinogen and increased d-dimer indicating disseminated intravascular coagulation likely from trauma and massive transfusion. Patients with DIC may exhibit jaundice, petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, as well as hematuria and hemoptysis.       

Massive transfusion protocol (MTP) is a treatment for massive ongoing hemorrhage. It has been arbitrarily defined as the replacement by transfusion of ≥10 units of whole blood (WB) or red blood cells (RBCs) in 24 hours as an approximation of the replacement of at least one blood volume. In patients who have experienced trauma, MTP is indicated for active bleeding requiring surgery or angioembolization or for persistent hemodynamic instability.         

Traumatic DIC is characterized by microvascular oozing, prolongation of the PT and aPTT more than would be expected by dilution, significant thrombocytopenia, low fibrinogen levels, and increased D dimer. This is sometimes referred to as "traumatic disseminated intravascular coagulation" (traumatic DIC), although this is a misnomer, as there are several differentiating factors when compared to DIC. One of which is that antifibrinolytics (tranexamic acid) are beneficial in treating trauma patients with massive transfusion and DIC, and they are not recommended for use in other cases of DIC.   

Option Analysis

❌ Wheezing :
Incorrect: Patients with anaphylactic reactions to transfusions can exhibit wheezing. Given the oozing and abnormal coagulation studies, this patient is likely experiencing a consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma. Wheezing is not an associated symptom of this condition.  
❌ Rigid abdomen  :
Incorrect: Patients who are unstable with peritonitis can develop a rigid abdomen. Based on the clinical scenario, this patient is likely experiencing consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma, and the presence of petechiae, and not a rigid abdomen, would be expected.       
✅ Petechiae :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urticaria  :
Incorrect: Urticaria can be seen in anaphylactic or hypersensitivity reactions to transfusions. It is not seen with consumptive coagulopathy, which this patient likely has. Petechiae would be expected with consumptive coagulopathy. 
❌ Edema in the extremities  :
Incorrect: Edema in the extremities is commonly seen in patients who have been in the ICU 24-48 hours after they have been over-resuscitated with IV fluids. This patient is experiencing consumptive coagulopathy from massive transfusion and trauma. Edema of the extremities is not a specific finding in this condition.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the trauma bay after being struck by a cyclist while she was walking. Her primary survey was initially intact, but shortly after the secondary survey, her blood pressure drops to 62/30 mmHg. Intravenous (IV) access is obtained, and a massive transfusion protocol is initiated. Focused assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) examination is positive, and the patient is taken to the operating room where a grade IV liver laceration is identified and repaired. Her abdomen is temporarily closed, and she is taken to the trauma intensive care unit (ICU) for additional resuscitation. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 87/67mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient remains intubated and sedated with a wound vac in place over the temporary laparotomy incision. Initial labs are pending. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a prolonged QTc of 510ms. Which of the following contributed to this patient’s ECG findings?

choices.text: Transfusion of Packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay after being struck by a cyclist while walking, resulting in a clinically significant liver laceration and initiation of a massive transfusion protocol (MTP). In the ICU, an ECG reveals a prolonged QTc interval. Given the recent MTP, this is likely due to the transfusion of packed red blood cells leading to hypocalcemia.       

Packed red blood cells are anticoagulated with sodium citrate and citric acid. Each 450 mL unit of blood contains 9 mmol of citrate. Massive transfusion leads to infusion of a large amount of citrate. Infused citrate can lead to a clinically significant fall in plasma-free calcium (ionized calcium) concentration, resulting in paresthesias and/or cardiac arrhythmias like prolonged QTc intervals.        

The risk of transfusion-induced hypocalcemia can be reduced by slowing the rate of transfusion and following physiologic markers such as blood pressure and corrected QT interval. Measuring the ionized calcium concentration with the ion-specific electrode on a blood gas machine is common. Calcium should be administered if patients are symptomatic from hypocalcemia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Transfusion of Prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is administered to reverse vitamin K antagonists in patients with major bleeding or those who need an urgent surgery/invasive procedure. It is not part of a massive transfusion protocol and would not lead to QTc prolongation. 
❌ Transfusion of Plasma:
Incorrect: Plasma is given to correct coagulation abnormalities. While it is part of the massive transfusion protocol, it would not lead to prolonged QTc of 510ms which is more likely caused by hypocalcemia.  
✅ Transfusion of Packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transfusion of Platelets:
Incorrect: Platelets are part of the massive transfusion protocol. Transfused platelets do not contain binding agents that would lead to clinically significant metabolic abnormalities like hypocalcemia.  
❌ Administration of Tranexamic Acid :
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that forms a reversible complex that displaces plasminogen from fibrin, resulting in the inhibition of fibrinolysis. TXA is often used for trauma patients with suspected moderate to severe hemorrhage who present within three hours of injury. It does not lead to QTc prolongation, nor is it part of the massive transfusion protocol.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of episodes of vomiting with streaks of blood. The patient was diagnosed with autoimmune thrombocytopenia 6 months ago and is treated with glucocorticoids and rituximab. The patient underwent a splenectomy 2 months ago. The patient has hypertension, treated with amlodipine, and depression for which he takes fluoxetine. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 104/53 mmHg. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is stabilized and receives several units of platelet with appropriate responses in platelet count. The patient is seen as an outpatient several weeks later. The patient has had no further episodes of bleeding, and repeat platelet count is 23,000/mm3. The physician starts the patient on a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. Which of the following is a serious adverse effect of this drug?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  13.2 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  5000/mm3 
 Platelet count    20,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient has immune thrombocytopenia and has failed to respond to first-line treatment options. Thrombopoietin receptor agonists (TPO-RA) are usually indicated in patients with ITP who fail to respond to splenectomy or in whom splenectomy is contraindicated.  

Romiplostim, and eltrombopag are TPO-RA that stimulate platelet production to treat thrombocytopenia. Romiplostim is recombinant thrombopoietin, whereas eltrombopag is a synthetic drug that acts as an agonist at the thrombopoietin receptor on myeloid progenitor cells to stimulate megakaryocyte production. Both romiplostim and eltrombopag are used to treat disorders where the body starts breaking down platelets, like chronic immune thrombocytopenia. These medications can exhibit serious side effects including increased risk of clot formation due to an increase in platelet production, and eltrombopag has been associated with liver toxicity and severe bleeding, limiting its use.  



Option Analysis

❌ Capillary leak syndrome:
Incorrect: Capillary leak syndrome, where fluids leak from the capillaries into the surrounding tissue causing severe edema, can be caused by therapy with sargramostim, a synthetic version of GM-CSF. It is often used to boost myeloid precursor production and maturation.   
❌ Bone pain:
Incorrect: Bone pain is a rare side effect of filgrastim, which results from high neutrophil production in the bone marrow. Filgrastim is a recombinant G-CSF and is used to correct neutropenia. This patient’s leukocyte count is within normal limits.  
✅ Thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy:
Incorrect: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy can develop in patients with JC virus infection, who are treated with natalizumab. Thrombopoietin receptor agonists (TPO-RAs) are not associated with PML.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus infection:
Incorrect: Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF), used for prophylaxis and therapy of graft-versus host disease in allogeneic stem cell transplantation, has been associated with increased susceptibility to invasive CMV infection. Thrombopoietin receptor agonists are not associated with an increased risk of CMV infections.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the urgent care with a 1-day history of left leg swelling and tenderness. She has no known past medical history, has not traveled recently, and has no family history of venous thromboembolism. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 112/80 mmHg, pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Her left leg appears swollen and erythematous, with the circumference of the left calf measuring 3.5 cm larger than the right. Tenderness is noted posteriorly over the upper left calf. Which of the following historical elements, if present, would confer the greatest risk for her current condition?
questions.solution:
The patient’s acute left leg swelling, erythema, and localized tenderness are concerning for deep vein thrombosis. Additional physical examination findings suggestive of DVT include warmth, palpation of the thrombotic vein, and pain with passive dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan sign).

When obtaining the patient’s history, it is essential to assess risk factors for DVT. Risk factors include age > 65 years, obesity, smoking, recent surgery or trauma, prolonged immobilization or hospitalization, personal or family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE), malignancy, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive or hormone replacement therapy. This not only helps to gauge the likelihood of DVT as the diagnosis, but whether the DVT was provoked or unprovoked which can change the management.

Pregnancy, hormone replacement therapy, and oral contraceptive use are significant risk factors to consider in women. Although the exact mechanism for inducing thrombosis is unclear, estrogen is known to affect multiple hemostatic variables. For women taking oral contraceptives, the risk of thrombosis increases within 6–12 months after initiating therapy. Oral contraceptives should be discontinued if identified as a provoking factor for DVT.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen use:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for deep vein thrombosis. Acetaminophen use is not considered a risk factor for the development of venous thromboembolism.  
✅ Oral contraceptive use:
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Infrequent physical exercise:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for a deep vein thrombosis. While immobilization is a prominent risk factor for venous thromboembolism, general exercise (or lack thereof) is not.  
❌ Low carbohydrate diet:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for a deep vein thrombosis. Specific diets are not considered a risk factor for the development of VTE.  
❌ Daily alcohol use:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and examination are concerning for deep vein thrombosis. Alcohol use is not considered a risk factor for venous thromboembolism.
